developmentContext.title: Development Context
developmentContext.content:
Antigua and Barbuda consists of two major islands and a number of smaller islands. The country with a population of 97,929 people remains a member of the Commonwealth. Geographically, the islands are low-lying, with the primary environmental influence being the Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea. Climatic features include relatively high and uniform temperatures throughout the year and steady easterly trade winds. Recent years have seen a dramatic increase in the frequency of hurricane activity and impacts. The marine and coastal ecosystems sustain Antigua & Barbuda’s sandy beaches and fisheries resources and protect against tropical storms and hurricane activity. Antigua and Barbuda’s marine and coastal environments are characterized by mangroves, coral reefs and sea-grass beds.

Tourism is a significant sector in the country, comprising more than half of the annual Gross Domestic Product (GDP), with other major industries including construction, agriculture, transport, communications, and banking and financial services. In addition, cruise tourism is a solid sub-sector, assuming an increasing tourism market share. The agriculture sector is also an essential part of the country’s economy, with major crops including fish, cotton, livestock, vegetables and pineapples.

The Government of Antigua and Barbuda places a high priority on education and usually allocates the largest share of the Government’s budget to education, recognizing that education is key to the advancement of its people and human capital development and the overall development competitiveness of the island nation.

successesInDevelopment.title: Successes in Development
successesInDevelopment.content:
Antigua and Barbuda’s HDI value for 2019 is 0.778, putting the country in the high human development category. Between 1990 and 2019, Antigua and Barbuda’s life expectancy at birth increased by 5.5 years and mean years of schooling increased by 2.3 years. Furthermore, the proportion of seats held by women in single or lower houses of parliament increased from 5.3 % in 2000 to 11.1% in 2020. In addition, Antigua and Barbuda’s GNI per capita increased by about 57.9 per cent between 1990 and 2019.

Over 95% of the population has access to essential services such as electricity, potable water, sanitation, and shelter. Access to health care and education also remains favourable.

Antigua and Barbuda is currently repositioning the twin-island nation to serve as the home and hub of the OECS blue economy efforts. In 2021, the Government established the Department of the Blue Economy and approved the country’s first Maritime Blue Economy Plan (MBEP). The MBEP sets out priorities and actions to broaden economic opportunities in sustainable manners towards enhancing economic resilience, improving socioeconomic standards, and creating opportunities for climate adaptation and reducing vulnerabilities.

challengesInDevelopment.title: Challenges in Development
challengesInDevelopment.content:
Antigua and Barbuda’s population is affected by the double burden of malnutrition. The population suffers from obesity (18.9 per cent of the adult population) and hunger (20.5 per cent of the total population). Antigua and Barbuda is among the top five countries most exposed to multiple hazards as 100 per cent of the land area, and 100 per cent of the population is exposed to 2 or more hazards a year. Regarding risk to economic output, the country is also among the top 20 countries at risk from two or more hazards, with an estimated 80.4 per cent of GDP that could potentially be impacted.

Antigua and Barbuda ranks second in the world for per capita waste generation. The twin-island nation generates 12 times the average world waste at 5.5 kg/person/day.

Antigua and Barbuda grapples with economic, social and environmental challenges such as a narrow resource base, heavy dependence and vulnerability to external markets exacerbated by small domestic markets; high costs for energy, infrastructure, transportation, communication and servicing; fragile natural environments and high levels of vulnerability to natural disasters; volatility in economic growth and limited opportunities for the private sector and a proportionately large reliance of their economies on their public sector. In addition, decades of unsustainable fiscal practices and weak institutional structures led to an extreme and unsustainable debt burden.
